content: ‘You have to be careful’ With military monitoring e-mails, gay troops get creative in writing home On a typical day during her deployment, Chief Petty Officer Lee Quillan spent time at the computer near her fellow sailors aboard the U.S.S. Higgins to send a message to her partner back home. But while other shipmates were sending “I love you” messages, Quillan was careful to avoid discussing topics that would show how emotionally attached she was to her significant other. She limited the length of her e-mails and tried not to stay online for long. “I just really kept it gender neutral,” she said. “You limit a lot of stuff you do talk about, even though you’re taking that precaution.” Quillan, who served overseas in the Navy from 1990 to 2003 and in Operation Iraqi Freedom, had to be careful about what she talked about with her partner, Jenny Kopfstein, to avoid being discharged under “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell,” a 1993 law that prohibits open gays from serving in the military. The U.S. military keeps a careful watch on communications to guard against leaks of sensitive information. But the surveillance means service members are at risk if they disclose they’re gay or reveal they have a same-sex partner. These communications could be intercepted and used as evidence for dismissal. Full article at ... >>>http://www.washblade.com/2009/5-8/news/national/14496.cfm

content: Considering that the Navy has cut off access to any third-party email (and rightly so) I am forced to wonder how it is exactly that a private email will "harm unit cohesion."

content: I think it's great that military personnel can now send E-mail (G-mail) to their family & friends. It sure beats keeping in contact by using the postal service which would take a month to get a reply to a letter you sent while overseas. When in port, we would use the telephones in town but getting an English speaking operator in a foreign country could be tricky depending on which country you were in. It was safe for gays to communicate with their loved ones while overseas back then, no one read your mail and the telephone exchanges were located in town. I remember when VHS/VCR's became popular in the late 70's and that did pose a problem for me once when my mate sent me a tape. I had popped in the tape and had only watched about a minute of it when another shipmate walked in,,, being fearful that the shipmate might see or hear something that might give away my orientation, I quickly hit the eject button and pulled the tape out. The fella gave me a quizzical look and no doubt wondered why I had acted so irrationally upon seeing him enter the room. I put the tape away and never did finish watching it until I returned stateside. It was just to risky aboard ship where privacy is almost non- existent. I wonder if they have those Internet café's in foreign ports nowadays, if you have a laptop you could safely do E-mails while in port during liberty.
